title: Will China's Three Gorges Dam fail before 1 October 2020?
preds: We are in the final hours. This will not likely happen.
Seems very solid even with earthquakes and rising of dam levels
Not unless it gets struck by a meteor.

The worst of the floodwater has subsided for now, with no failure. Reports on the ground are less alarming, and there is very little time left now before the deadline. With a Dam-Failure Baseline already being very, very low (virtually negligible) over such short time frames, the chance of failure over the next week is small enough to be incalculable. Therefore, going with an estimated 1%, just to be on the safe side.
Water level has gone up again, but will not reach dangerous levels before October 1st even if it continues to rise at the current rate. Still keeping a small percentage open for the unexpected.
chance decreases with less time until resolution.

From 2003 to November 2008, 5503 earthquakes - roughly 1100 earthquakes per year (365 days). 
1100/365 Roughly 3 per day
8 days left - 24%
2 days will be 6%
I guess I'm a little unsure whether to compound the likelihood if an earthquake doesn't occur or each day resets like a coin toss.

Days for an earthquake to occur are reducing. 
Minimal rain
I think the probability has to be >0 (even if only slightly).
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yWxJYAWchJs 24 hour watch shows water level to be 5 metres lower than the warning level.

Latest data show water level decreasing (https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:2020_Three_Gorges_Dam_water_level.svg), but (a) thèse data are a week old and (b) dam collapse does not always happen at maximum capacity, but high volumes of water may weaken the structure that may fail at a later date. I'm pretty sure it won't give out in the next 10 days, but the difference between low and no probability is huge, so I'm staying away from a 0 forecast.
No news is good news. No change for now, because of passage of time.
As the rainfall has subsided it is quite unlikely that the dam would give up now.

Dam was completed in 2006 and is likely proper maintenance is carried out on this dam due to the reliance of locals for high power output. It is also a safety concern in relation to floods
The dam flooded various areas and has therefore increased risk of landslides locally
There is minimal rainfall during September so a reduced likelihood of landslides
The lifespan is somewhere between 50-100 years, especially with maintenance
The dam sits on a seismic fault and the land in the area is experiencing erosion
Long-term studies on the Yangtze Three Gorges area found that the crust in or around the dam site is stable, but a tectonic background exists that could induce seismic activity. Earthquakes: 
o	2008 – 4.1 magnitude;
o	2013 – 5.1 magnitude  
From June 2003 to November 2008, 5503 earthquakes (M ≥ 0) were recorded by the Three Gorges seismic network. This total includes 4362 earthquakes of 0. 0 < M < 0. 9, 1030 earthquakes of 1.0 ≤ M < 2. 0, 106 earthquakes of 2. 0 ≤ M < 3. 0, and 4 earthquakes of 3.0 ≤ M < 4.0.
Difficult to determine the magnitude of the next earthquake and when that will take place but there is only 12 days for it to take place and cause the dam to fail.
Increasing my very low probabilities a little bit, because I realize I'm not really that well calibrated for low percentages.

Decreasing with time and weather. Interesting correlation. https://pjmedia.com/columns/stacey-lennox/2020/09/11/china-could-be-creating-crises-in-asia-that-americans-know-nothing-about-free-tibet-activist-says-n913448
Something that seems strange is going on at the dam;  they don't seem to be able to maintain a steady outflow, and the water level is rising again.

There are 2 ways I think this might happen:
 - Tropical Hurricane -> about a 1 in 1000 every year, and since hurricane season in china is almost over even lower
 - All-out conflict with Taiwan, India -> probability approaching  0
probably something like 0.01%
maintaining. non-zero chance, but below .2% probability, so rounding down.
Given the time-bound nature of the question and the fact that the worst of the monsoons in China have already passed, I don't think the dams are likely to fail by the end of this month.

Although I think the failure of any dam is a non-zero probability and the issues that with Three Gorges Dam are of greater concern than a dam with an established track record of success.  In any given year I'd rate the probability of a failure occurring is in the low single digits (expressed in%).  If I were an engineer on Three Gorges Dam or a leader in China I would be both looking to improve the dam and ensure that there are solid contingency plans for the surrounding area.  However, given the short term nature of the question and that the hight of monsoon season is passed in China I'm rating the possible of a failure as 0%.
@pstamp That was an interesting simulation.  Thank you for sharing.

bent but not broken, in the time remaining seems increasingly unlikely. https://www.breitbart.com/national-security/2020/09/04/chinese-villagers-communist-party-flooded-us-protect-big-cities/

Unless it gets hit by a meteor or Godzilla, this thing is not going anywhere.

No news is good news. 
Here´s a nice simulation, what would happen, if it did fail:

Very little time left; the crowd is at 1%.

The worst case scenario seems to be behind us: 
- outflow is back to average level for flooding season 
- water level continues to trend down  http://3gd.mooo.com/ Please note that this data has its drawbacks (in the faq)
""On multiple occasions inflow < outflow yet the water level is going up. As one anon said, "CCP might just have the real data, and then decide by committee what levels they want to share, and then get the water system operator to tell them how far is too far." We can't argue with that. But the trend lines are potentially indicative""
Previously 1%; down to zero. The structure has been slightly damaged but not in imminent risk of failure.
decrease after pass of weather system

3gd.mooo.com 
Downward trend suggests relaxation with brunt of rain over.
Not zero, but unlikely and less than 1%
Decreasing chances as we get closer to October...it is still standing.

20 Notable Dam Failures in the World per Year = 200 / (2009 - 2000 + 1)
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dam_failure   China has 20% of Large Dams in the World ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_dams_and_reservoirs_in_China   I will assume that Notable Dam Failures only occur with Large Dams. Total Number of Notable Chinese Dam Failures Per Year = 4 = 20 * 0.2 The list of Notable Dams in China has approx 170 Dams including the Three Gorges Dam ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_dams_and_reservoirs_in_China     Three Gorges Dam Failure in 2020 = 2% =  4 / 170 Due to concerns expressed about the structural integrity of the Three Gorges Dam I will increase this forecast to 10%.
Continuing to trend down to deadline
Updating due to one month to deadline.

I think that season which causes the most danger of flooding is passing.  
The dam managers seem to have calibrated and perfected their efforts.
I am reverting to "normal" base-rate.

Water level is still high at the dam, and drops slowly. Probably floodgates have been closed very soon after the inflow decreased in order to bring relief to downstream inhabitants, e.g. in Yichang.
It's risky, the water management admin obviously bets the monsoon season 2020 will be over.

Down to 1%
Should probably be zero
Overall level is high for this time of year, but the rains relent, and they've reduced the outflow. 
The key factor is they reduced the outflow, which conveys confidence IMO
They are back in control of the water level

Per a colleague of mine, the Gorges dam has been more full than this several times. 
From a certain research group:
"Three Gorges Dam.  “Whatever it takes” is no exaggeration regarding what 
Beijing has been doing and will do to protect the Three Gorges Dam, the world’s 
largest hydro power project.  The result -- regions both upstream and downstream 
suffer more, in particular the downstream, but in exchange for reducing the worst 
case chances.  We expect it to stay safe.  There has never been, worldwide, a 
collapse this big in history. "

The Chinese government will sacrifice down stream territory as it has already demonstrated. Dam failure would be shameful in the eyes of the world. Only catastrophic rainfall exceeding the ability to release water could cause a failure.
Not going to happen short of the hand of God getting involved.
It appears that it is being well-managed.

40 dam failures world since 2000. The worst failure of a dam in a larger period was in china in 1975, 
china has 50k réservoirs associés with dams, and the covid is restricting people flow and maintenance tasks. The risk of failure is better than zero by a significant amount. The risk is certainly not zero and I'm beginning to question the verity of gjp when the whole 'game' seems to be to predict whatever the crowd is and then your score is magnified or when I'm seeing people with multiple accounts manipulating the crowd predictions by simply predicting multiple times over several accounts.  9 days, with typically 111.7mm

.29/…11.17% tot precipitous for the whole year only in aug on avg “the restrictions in human flow during the COVID-19 pandemic in mainland China halted regular dam maintenance, dam inspection, training of officials and the construction of hydraulic projects, which were scheduled in the winter and spring of 2020.[33] In response to concerns about the stability of the dam, the state-run Global Times tabloid claimed that the Three Gorges Dam was "safe for heavy rainfall" and "not at risk of collapse",[34] and that some media organizations outside of mainland China made a disproportionate issue out of a distortion of the dam.[35]” https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_China_floods “The alarming water level gave rise to rumors that the dam is under structural strain and nearby residents should evacuate. “Speculation that the dam is an impending disaster have long circulated online both at home and abroad.”  Dams are typically designed to cope with a so-called 1-in-100-year flood event…[but]…The 1-in-100-year event is perhaps happening every five years” Albeit a year old article, but still apropos:
The world's ageing dams are not built for ever more extreme weather Read more: https://www.newscientist.com/article/2212427-the-worlds-ageing-dams-are-not-built-for-ever-more-extreme-weather/#ixzz6W7LATK1B, 2AUG19

Actually I thought I'd correct for my overly pessimistic view by forecasting zero. Now I found out that the city of Yinchang, for which the graph "Downstream: Yichang" is plotted with two curves (Current level/Flow)
http://3gd.mooo.com/ isn't really downstream but MUST be upstream (30° 42′ 16″ N , 111° 17′ 19″ E), if there aren't two cities in the same province that by chance have the same name.
If that holds, than its ugly news: what translated into the fifth wave at the dam and 75k m³/s inflow, seems to be correlated with the first little peak of flow on 16 August 2020, at about 42,000m³/s of flow.
This means that it's far from over at the dam, since after two days of short break at 40,000m³/s the flow rose to even 51,000m³/s at its peak on 21/22 August 2020. Projected proportionately into the inflow at the location of the Three Gorges Dam, this means it could even hit 90,000 to 100,000m³/s of inflow tomorrow for a short peak. Looks very dangerous.

No fault of the Chinese, but I’m reasoning the dam was built to withstand a 1 in 1000 year flood. Which, over a 10 years would mean a 1% chance of failure. Not small odds. Problem for China is, it’s at its limit, and another half meter of rain is predicted to fall in the catchment over the next ten days. It will take time to arrive, but it’s going to be a very close run thing.
Very rare for dams to fail due to excess water. The dam can always run off water to minimize risk of failure.

At current speed (roughly +2.5meters per day), water level will have reached absolute maximum capacity within just five days. Current heavy rains, near capacity.  The probability is still low, but just above zero.

the water level is rising by approx. 1 meter per day as of 18 August 2020, to 159m compared to a low of 153m on 14 August.
In the meantime, outflow has expanded to the highest level on record since 20 July 2020 to almost 45k m³ per sec. Problematically, inflow has expanded even quicker, to currently about 67k m³ per sec, which leaves a surplus of more than 20k m³/s for the dam to hold for the time being, or up to 1.75mn m³ per day. Highest water level on record will be reached on 23/24 August at current pace. Spills might happen from 27 August and through September.
If it did happen, it would have been a result of human error with the flood controls and not due to the dam's structure failing.

"The average amount of annual precipitation is: 999.9 mm (39.37 in)", typical jun/jul months are the wettest with the month raising concern being about 200mm.
The dam operators are saying that the measured flow was 61k m^3/s and that the design threshold is twice that...the dam is 26 years old from conception but not actually fully complete until 2015 so I'd say that makes it reasonably new...not that new things don't fail...it's not a zero chance...but the designer/operators hubris in saying that "nothing could topple the dam in 500 years" is colorful. All of Hubei province is (according to wikipedia) ~186km^2 and the catchment area for the three gorges reservoir looks like something about 1/3 to 2/3 (so 62000-124000 km^2) of the total area of the province. There is about 34.8mm predicted total average rainfall for the next ten days. Which could produce somewhere between 1000 m^3 and 519000 m^3 which is not the measured flow rate at the dam only the area measured precipitation...Then too there was typhoon lekima on 10 Aug and a pos.tropical storm in the next three to four days moving through the SCS.

The immediate flood has passed, so a failure at this point would require another massive monsoon and/or that the damage to the dam is much more serious than has been admitted. This seems extremely unlikely but not impossible.
re-affirming.  The water level in the reservoir continues to fall as inflows have decreased.  Releases have stayed high, but not at the max.

The worst seems to be over, but water levels are still high. The dam is said to have been 'deformed slightly' but a breach appears very unlikely now. This article is almost three weeks old, and seems to mark the point of highest risk.

Low probability. China's leadership knows that the world is watching them and they will do everything in their power to prevent failure. It's a question of their standing in the world.
Yes, but the news about it will not leak out until after 1 October 2020

The conspiracy theory behind this is weird but oh well. Seems improbable, I've found articles like this about the dam going back to 2003 so it seems unlikely from the offset.  If there was information about unnecessary stress on the dam the CCP would not be sharing this. It seems that whilst the July rain fall was unprecedented it coped.

Currently the Dam if accounts are to be believed is quiet stressed.  If the 10 day regional forecast is to be believed this will be the 4th significant flood the Dam has faced this year and officials claim there are significant vibrations from the currently open 7 sluice gates

We have now passed the peak of the rainy season with no indication that the Dam was ever or is about to fail due to precipitation. It is still possible that some cataclysmic event (earthquake) could disrupt or destroy it, but in the two months remaining, that is an incredibly remote possibility.
It was built before things got really cheap in China.

I’ve shared this link before, and recommend others follow him on Twitter for the duration of this forecast - he has provided reliably accurate updates on the TGD. One of the questions I had was what happened to all the water upstream, such as in Cuntan. He provides a plausible explanation here [1], which is why I’m increasing my probability by 1%. Seems unlikely, a large project like this will have been designed to the extreme, and I would expect they would allow a controlled release of large volumes of water before any large threat to the dam itself occurred. As per this article the threat has largely passed. It was brought to my attention that the Chinese Approach to flood control is the opposite of the Corp Of Engineers in the United States. Here we hold the water to prevent a flood, in a flood pool behind a dam. There the philosophy is to speed the water downstream, dams are collectors for a drainage system. Ergo the dam has different set of engineering requirements. So the durability under record prolonged flood pools is unknown.
Flooding should be included in the stability of the dam

Even after two large inflow peaks, the dam remains below max level (175m), but the rainy season still has at least a month to go and could extend through September if the unusual conditions this summer persist.  The monitoring info (http://3gd.mooo.com, thx @Anneinak!) does suggest that the dam engineers are controlling the level well but it also shows the limits to what they can do, the outflow stays in the 40-45K m3/s range throughout. Still seems unlikely that a dam designed (partially) for flood control would fail under conditions that seem to be within its operating tolerances (need more research on this...).

First off, I have to self-report a bias against China. The fact that this has come to light, despite the interests of the Chinese government to keep it under wraps, is a sign that the concerns are warranted, and probably more serious than reported. Of course, people have been saying that the dam will break since 2018, and it hasn't happened. Though recently, sections of the dam have already moved under the growing water pressure, water is being released as a precaution and over 30 million Chinese have been evacuated. The weather forecast for Zigui County forecasts rain to continue incessantly in the next 10 days. The government has already blasted open a dam in Anhui. Chinese Dams have been poorly maintained and rarely reinforced. Furthermore, the Dam is more vanity project than hydro-electic engineering marvel (Mao Zedong was obsessed with the dam); in spite of its enormous size, it fails to produce as much electricity as the Itaipu Dam - a dam with 2/3rd its capacity and turbines. The US Glen Canyon Dam also failed in response to the floods of 1983. Also noteworthy: just days after the first filling of the reservoir of the Three Gorges Dam, around 80 hairline cracks were observed in the dam's structure. Since then, Chinese inspection has stated that "163,000 concrete units were assessed (...) with a pass rate of 100%". However, the dam has not been inspected by Dutch dam experts, despite Sino-Dutch infrastructural cooperation. In conclusion: It's made in China, of course it's gonna break.

State intervention will occur in time due to the financial impact a dam fail will entail. Chinese CCP will not want to be seen to work with other states to resolve this but back-channel mechanisms for getting funding in place while allowing the perception of Chinese state acting alone will occur. This would have a gobally significant impact and all steps will be taken to ensure the dam does not fail.
China would dump water and flood downstream before having a public disaster.

However, this year China has seen record-breaking levels of rainfall and monsoon season lasts until the end of September, so it's failure is not completely out of the question.

Monsoon flood levels here peak in August and forecast for next 10 days is not continuous rainfall. The static nature of the pressure waves creating high pressure accross sibieria is having significant impact on the monsoon season accross asia. This has increased the levels of rainfall above usual.
Equally it seems that protections are being made for the Dam including ensuring sufficent pressure differential across the dam by alliviating some of the pressure downstream.

A failure in this case will be a result of two factors: 1) record rainfall - the last heaviest rainfall was in 1998 (when the dam was not yet built), which killed thousands of people and displaced millions. The rainfall forecast is expected to be severe - 10 cm per hour in certain regions for another 5 days. 
2) Strength of the dam - Although a new dam, China has accepted that there is a slight deformity in the peripherals. Already, the height of storage is 162 m as against 145 m.  Hence, it depends on how long the rainfall will continue and how far the officials will continue the height. If the rainfall decreases in the coming days, it will reduce the chances. Meanwhile, considering minor deformity and rainfall for a few more days, the chances are less than 25% as of today.
China's Three Gorges Dam has been a major project run by the CCP and is poised to hold much more than the current crisis entails.

Reading this question carefully reveals there are actually two independent events that need to be considered 1.) Structural failure of the dam and 2.) An overflow or overtopping of the dam (meets the criteria of "uncontrolled release"). The dam is a relatively new reinforced concrete gravity dam. The main body was completed in 2006. The probability of that type of dam built as recently as 2006 failing in the question timeframe is negligible. Not putting weight in reports of cracking. All concrete cracks. What matters is the ingress of water into the cracks and the initiation of corrosion of the steel reinforment. This happens but takes time. The question is really what is the return period (recurrence interval) of the flood event that would cause an overtopping/overflowing of the dam...adjusted for the remaining question timeframe and current flooding levels

There does not appear to be a definition of the term ‘Dam Fail’ and an associated quantification of degree of structural damage. Such an event is described as an uncontrolled release of water due to structural or deficient issues with the dam and range from minor to catastrophic.
The National Interagency Committee on Dam Safety rates dams as high hazard dams(potential loss of life); Significant dams (no loss of life, but severe economic, environmental or serious damage; Low hazard dams causing limited damage to property. The 3 Gorges Dam is obviously an extremely high Hazard dam.
However, the question concerns a dam fail and not the extent of damage and so a 'fail' could be something minor.

1% initial estimate, based on survey of comments by users below. This is an initial estimate, and I will be updating in the weeks to come. Initial assumptions: 
-Alarming stories, whatever their truth, are substantially more likely to be reported and distributed than "everything is fine" stories. So alarm about the TGD (Three Gorges Dam) failing should be discounted until further investigation. There were rumours in 2019 about a potential collapse [1]
-We can disregard anything written in the Global Times, as it is a propaganda front for the CCP.
-Dams have suffered "sudden, rapid, and uncontrolled releases of impounded water" before, though I am as yet uncertain about a base rate. I have set this estimate at 1% to reflect the fact that it "could happen"
-Various forecasters have noted the low quality of construction common in much of China. Against that, I agree with @ManuPV, that TGD is a prestige project (not a public school or housing block) and highly likely to have been the subject of stringent quality controls. It's failure would be a national humiliation. I will adjust upward if heavy rains continue or increase in intensity. [1] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-hydropower-threegorges/three-gorges-dam-is-safe-say-china-officials-dismissing-online-rumors-idUSKCN1U40QB
Starting at 10% . Not sure how we will really now what failure is.. Looks like rain will continue until at least beginning of August. But this is a relatively new dam

The 3GD is a gravity dam, but the blocks are resting on the riverbed, not dug in. This is causing deformation throughout the structure. Construction is likely shoddy and the quality team that inspected the dam were from the same company that built it - not independently done. The CCP came out yesterday(?) to say that there is some deformation in the dam, but nothing to worry about. This alone from the CCP is unusual. In my estimation, the CCP would rather flood Wuhan downstream than see their flagship fall. That said, they may not have a choice. As the heavy rains in the region continue, water is making its way back into the Yangtze and thus the reservoir. Not all of the rain we've seen in the past has yet entered the reservoir. The water level is already at 164m, 175m is the warning of collapse, 185m and it's gone. The final and most likely catastrophic failure is the spillways being damaged - we're seeing this on at least two of the spillways on the livestream. A large chunk appears to be broken off spillway #6 and there is evidence of cavitation in spillway #2. If the damage to the spillways continues, the dam will fail, and badly.

dams are typically designed for 500 year events due to their importance and risk to public. There are also many redundancies in the engineering and construction of such structures to allow for a "ductile" behaviour so failures are gradual and with signs so the collapses can be prevented. Having said that, quality of construction and recent floods may prevent timely action and lead to its collapse.
I am forecasting low, but with the amount of rain they have got so far and the amount expected to continue to rise I will be checking back on this one often.

This looks unlikely, but how unlikely seems difficult to estimate: on the one hand, quality of construction in China is poor and cutting corners is a way of life. On the other this is a flagship project, which means that there must have been stringent quality controls (in contrast with the standard situation in China). Unfortunately this is inside view. I did not try to make a historic review of dams failing around the world or in China. However the Banqiao dam failure in 1975 readily comes to mind: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banqiao_Dam
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1975_Banqiao_Dam_failure and catastrophic floods have been a common recurrence along Chinese history.

This is a gravity concrete dam, which means it relies on its own weight for stability. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Gorges_Dam There have been heavy rains in the region which continue as of the time of writing.  The dam is 181m high and the design maximum water level is 176m. Dams are designed to last hundreds of years, though climate change could mean that the original design assumptions have become outdated. There is a very slight chance of the dam "failing" within the next few months and releasing a sudden rapid uncontrolled flow downstream - just above zero. https://asia.nikkei.com/Economy/Natural-disasters/Anxiety-grows-as-water-level-in-Three-Gorges-Dam-increases "The Three Gorges Dam in Hubei Province is now holding back water from the Yangtze River, China's longest, at a level topping 162 meters as of Tuesday afternoon".  Some reports say the dam was built to hold 145 meters of water but actually that figure refers to the level at which water is released downstream in order to smooth out flood flows and maintain capacity in the reservoir. Discharge in recent days and weeks has been between 20 and 30 thousand cumecs, but this has gone up to 40k in the past, so there is still some cushion. Probably the greatest risk is of failure of one or more major dams upstream, unleashing a flood surge that could overtop the dam.

There were 3,523 incidents of dam failure from 1954 to 2013 (He et al. 2008; Zhao 2014) that caused significant loss of life and economic losses in china.
This averages out to 67 dam failures, of various sizes per year. There are approx 87,000 dams in total. Given this, the three gorges dam broadly speaking has .08 chance of failing this year. There is significant flooding atm, which could increase probability of failure, but the concrete dam wall is 181 m (594 ft) high above the rock basis and has a max capacity water level of 175 m  (wiki)
Water level currently seems to be at 145-7 m from the articles I can find, which is well within capacity. 
The dam has passed quality checks, is a relatively new project (old dams fail more often) and there's a large amount of research done on seismic activity in the area. 
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1674984715300756
https://journal.probeinternational.org/2014/04/07/three-gorges-dam-triggers-frequent-seismic-activities/
https://www.slu.edu/news/2018/september/earthquake-research.php
There are rumors of buckling and deformation and a google earth image going around (https://www.foxnews.com/world/integrity-of-chinas-three-gorges-dam-questioned-despite-china-officials-dismissing-it-as-safe) but I looked myself, and google earth currently shows shows no buckling, nor could I find any inconsistencies, so Ima say probs not, image seems fake.  Long story short, is the dam gonna prevent flooding downstream? Maybe not, its effectiveness at doing so seems questionable based off the articles. This, however, isn't the issue at hand. We're asking is the worlds largest dam gonna fail in the next three months after passing safety checks, having research available about seismic activity in the area and currently within capacity? Highly unlikely. If upstream dams start to fail and/or if water levels breach capacity, then it gets more likely. But til then, low low chance.
Doubt it, not more than 1% on this timescale.

All major engineering projects are designed to sustain what we often believe are unbelievable conditions. However, there is obviously a non-zero chance of a dam collapse given the magnitude of the project, and the fact that there are upstream dams that could further stress limits. I expect that the chance here is low though. I would guess that in order for this to happen, we would have to see at least 1 of the upstream dams fail, if not multiple. This should have been a design consideration for the engineers going in. Can watch the news over the next few days to see if this occurs.

The crowd is confirming what I had presumed: 1. this is unlikely, 2. we can't know, 3. we have no reason to presume some impending failure... The fact that this question was being posed, I presumed the folks at GJO knew something I didn't, but the crowd is coming to the rescue.

(There seems to be controversy about the buckling mentioned in this article)  https://www.globaltimes.cn/content/1195357.shtml https://www.theamericanconservative.com/dreher/china-three-gorges-dam-collapse/ This is a gravity dam,, and it relies upon the construction itself to stand.  It was 50 ft Above flood level.  I see this as a concern without being a high probability event.

This question talks about the failure of a $ 32 Billion project completed in 2012. We have roughly 9 weeks from today till when the question is resolved.  5% for Yes is a good baseline to start.  While the dam is currently holding more water than it is designed for, water can always be released if things get bad. The reason why they would be holding more water is in order to prevent the catchment areas from getting flooded.

There is no way that I can know if the concrete was proper quality, the construction was proper, or the quality control process functioned properly.  I know that inChina, unlike America, if a major showpiece catastrophically fails and humiliates the nation there will be long prison  sentences and death. This is factor that motivates engineers not to be part of a screwup.  The Dam was never going to prevent down stream flooding so water will be released  but in a controlled manner.

I hope it won't, but the risk should definitely be considered. The floodings are the result of rainfall that is to be observed in my rough estimate only every 200 to 400 years, and comparable maybe to the environment and the anomalies of the Rhine floodings of the years 1374 and 1784. https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pegel_K%C3%B6ln Large dams always bear the risk that in case of failure extreme flood waves are released, which could kill tens of thousands of inhabitants living close to the water line, in case evacuations cannot be completed before failure. This is, among other reasons such as ecologic degradation of the river(s), why projects like the Three Gorges Dam have come under close scrutiny and would probably not be built by today's knowledge of the matter. Sadly, the Three Gorges Dam has been politicized as a prestigious signature project of the CP, so rationality and good reasons could not stop it in the first place. As the Dam is constructed rather recently, it should be of good quality (concrete, steel, engineering,...), but: we must only hope it will have been engineered to withstand an 500 years-event and had an orderly and proper maintenance before. With the sheer size in mind, I cannot imagine that any adhoc-emergency maintenance could stop the Dam from failing, once weaknesses come to light. Keep fingers crossed that the rain will stop and the water can run off slowly producing electricity instead of suffering and death... EDIT: further large amounts of rain of up to 3 to 5 inches (100 to 150mm) are to be expected across the China midlands per day(!) for the next six days.
